comment.shortText: Data type to represent an axis-aligned bounding box (AABB).
comment.text:
Bounding boxes are often used for approximations of geometric shapes or for certain
categories of performance-optimized spatial calculations, such as spatial index queries
and viewbox culling.

A box in Math2d is defined by its `minX`, `minY`, `maxX`, and `maxY` edges. Where
relevant and unless documented otherwise, boxes are interpreted as _closed_ regions,
i.e. they include those points that lie along their edges.

```
┌╴x+
y+     minY ─┌──────┐
       maxY ─└──────┘
             │      │
           minX    maxX
```

Math2d chooses to lay out this data in a
flat object structure, as opposed to an array or nested arrays, for ease of use and performance.

comment.shortText: Min-X boundary of this box, typically the "right" edge.

Max-Y boundary of this box. Note that this could be either the "top" or the "bottom" of the
box, depending on how your rendering and coordinate system are laid out.
Min-X boundary of this box, typically the "left" edge.

Min-Y boundary of this box. Note that this could be either the "top" or the "bottom" of the
box, depending on how your rendering and coordinate systems are laid out.

Data type to represent a line in 2D space, i.e. some initial point in the plane plus a unit-length direction
vector coming from that point.
comment.text:
The data representation of a line and the similar {@link IRay} type is actually the same, but Math2d chooses
to export these two names for ease of clarity. Functions that may interpret Rays and Lines differently will be
named differently to prevent ambiguity, such as
{@link polygonIntersectLineIterator} vs {@link polygonIntersectRayIterator}.

Where relevant, a line is parameterized according to _t_ with movement of distance _t_ along its direction vector.
In this mapping, _t_ = 0 represents the initial point (x0, y0), _t_ > 0 moves in the direction of its vector,
and _t_ < 0 in the opposite direction.

comment.shortText: x-coordinate of the direction of the line, relative to its initial point
y-coordinate of the direction of the line, relative to its initial point
x-coordinate of the line's initial point
y-coordinate of the line's initial point
Data type to hold a 2D affine transformation matrix.
comment.text:
Two-dimensional vector graphics operations are usually represented using an affine transform matrix,
i.e. a linear 2x2 matrix plus a 2D translation. Math2d chooses to lay out this data in a
flat object structure, as opposed to an array or nested arrays, for ease of use and performance.
The field names used here match other standards, like the native DOMMatrix
specification and the Canvas reference APIs.

```
⎡a c e⎤
⎣b d f⎦
```

Per usual linear algebra, multiplying a vector `v = (x, y)` according to this affine matrix is defined by:

```
⎡a c e⎤ ⎛x⎞   ⎛ax + cy + e⎞
⎢b d f⎥ ⎜y⎟ = ⎜bx + dy + f⎟
⎣0 0 1⎦ ⎝1⎠   ⎝     1     ⎠
```

comment.shortText: Col 1, row 1 component, usually called `m11` in a 4x4 graphics matrix.
Col 1, row 2 component, usually called `m12` in a 4x4 graphics matrix.
Col 2, row 1 component, usually called `m21` in a 4x4 graphics matrix.
Col 2, row 2 component, usually called `m22` in a 4x4 graphics matrix.
Col 3, row 1 component, usually called `tx` or `m41` in a 4x4 graphics matrix.
Col 3, row 2 component, usually called `ty` or `m42` in a 4x4 graphics matrix.
Data type to hold the result of find the nearest point on a piece of geometry.

The value of the distance from the computed nearest point to the original point.
This may be the actual (Euclidean) distance, the signed euclidean distance, or the distance squared,
depending on the actual nearest function called.
comment.text:
Consult the docs for the particular nearest function being called for specifics on what value
is returned in this field.

comment.shortText: The parameterization of the nearest point along the geometry.
The x-coordinate of the nearest point.
The y-coordinate of the nearest point.
Data type to hold the result of a point intersection between two pieces of geometry.

Whether an intersection was found. If the return value of a function is `false` for the `exists` field,
the other Intersection values will be set to `NaN` and should not be interpreted.

The parameterization of the intersection along the first shape's geometry,
if an intersection point was found.

The parameterization of the intersection along the second shape's geometry,
if an intersection point was found.
The x-coordinate of the intersection, if an intersection point was found.
The y-coordinate of the intersection, if an intersection point was found.

Data type to represent a ray in 2D space, i.e. an initial point in the plane plus a unit-length direction
vector coming from that point.
comment.text:
The data representation of a ray and the similar {@link ILine} type is actually the same, but Math2d chooses
to export both names for clarity of usage. Functions that may interpret Rays and Lines differently will be
named differently to prevent ambiguity,
such as {@link polygonIntersectLineIterator} vs {@link polygonIntersectRayIterator}.

Where relevant, a ray is parameterized according to _t_ ≥ 0 with movement of distance _t_ along its direction vector.
In this mapping, _t_ = 0 represents the initial point (x0, y0).

comment.shortText:
x-coordinate of the direction vector of the ray.
A ray's (dirX, dirY) direction vector is a unit vector emanating from its initial point.

y-coordinate of the direction vector of the ray.
A ray's (dirX, dirY) direction vector is a unit vector emanating from its initial point.
x-coordinate of the ray's initial point
y-coordinate of the ray's initial point
Data type to represent a 2D line segment.
comment.text:
A segment object holds two (x, y) endpoints, representing the line segment connecting those points
in the plane. Unlike the similar {@link IRay} and {@link ILine} types, a segment has finite length.

For a series of connected line segments, see the {@link IPolyline} data type.

Where relevant, a segment is parameterized according to linear interpolation
between its endpoints, where _t_ = 0 represents its starting vertex and _t_ = 1 its
ending vertex.

comment.shortText: x-coordinate of the starting vertex of the segment.
x-coordinate of the ending vertex of the segment.
y-coordinate of the starting vertex of the segment.
y-coordinate of the ending vertex of the segment.
Data type to hold an (x, y) value.
comment.text:
The vector type in the Math2d package is used interchangeably to represent both points in the plane
and vectors as in linear algebra.

Math2d chooses to lay out the (x, y) values in a JavaScript object rather than an array
for ease of use. After carefully benchmarking that difference, it's been confirmed that this
does not sacrifice performance or memory compactness.

comment.shortText: x-coordinate of the vector
y-coordinate of the vector

An alias for `number[]`. Data type to represent a polygon in the plane,
as an interleaved sequence of vertex coordinates.
comment.text:
The `IPolygon` type is just an alias for an array of number values. For example,
a polygon with vertices v0, v1, v2, ..., vn is represented in Math2d as the array:

```
[v0x, v0y, v1x, v1y, v2x, v2y, ..., vnx, vny]
```

Unlike the similar {@link IPolyline} type, a polygon's perimeter is always interpreted as a closed shape.

Where relevant, a polygon with _N_ sides is parameterized according to _t_,
where integer values of _t_ correspond to the polygon's
vertices in order, and smooth values of _t_ therein interpolate linearly between adjacent vertices, with an
additional segment connecting the last vertex to the first.

Math2d chooses to lay out this data in a flattened (interleaved) array, as opposed to e.g. an array of
IVecs, for performance and more compact storage.

comment.shortText:
An alias for `number[]`. Data type to represent a sequence of connected line segments in the plane,
as an interleaved array of vertex coordinates.
comment.text:
The `IPolyline` type is just an alias for an array of number values. For example,
a polyline connecting the points p0, p1, p2, ..., pn in space is represented in Math2d as the array:

```
[p0x, p0y, p1x, p1y, p2x, p2y, ..., pnx, pny]
```

Unlike the similar {@link IPolygon} type, a polyline is not necessary closed.

Where relevant, a polyline with _N_ points is parameterized according to _t_ with linear interpolation between
adjacent points by index. For example, _t_ = 3.5 represents the midpoint between the index 3 and index 4 point
of the polyline, _t_ = 0 is its first point, and _t_ = _N_ is its final point. Any _t_ value falling
outside of the range [0, _N_] is disallowed.

Math2d chooses to lay out this data in a flattened (interleaved) array, as opposed to e.g. an array of
IVecs, for performance and more compact storage.

comment.shortText:
Sentinel value for the result of {@link boxGetOutCode} to represent that
the point was outside the max-X edge of the box.

Sentinel value for the result of {@link boxGetOutCode} to represent that
the point was outside the max-Y edge of the box.

Sentinel value for the result of {@link boxGetOutCode} to represent that
the point was outside the min-X edge of the box.

Sentinel value for the result of {@link boxGetOutCode} to represent that
the point was outside the min-Y edge of the box.
Creates a new Box object in memory, with all values initialized to `NaN`.
comment.text:
Data allocation functions like `boxAlloc()` are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can
severely hurt code readability and maintainability, so it's best to avoid
such optimization if you can.

comment.shortText: Copies values from an existing IBox into a new box.

comment.text: source to copy values from
destination box to copy values to

comment.shortText: Computes the area intersection of the two box regions.
comment.text:
Given two boxes, this function computes the region where they overlap.
If the two boxes do not overlap,
the returned value will be an empty box, i.e. with `maxX < minX` or `maxY < minY`.

The similar function {@link boxIntersectsBox} will check whether two
boxes intersect, without actually computing that intersection region.
first box to compute intersection for
second box to compute intersection for

comment.shortText: Compute the smallest bounding box that contains both given boxes.
comment.text:
For example, if one box contains the other, this method returns the larger box.
If the two boxes don't intersect, this method returns a bounding region that covers both boxes.

comment.shortText: Determines whether the second box is completely enclosed in the first.
comment.text:
Returns true if the second box is contained in the first.
Each box is treated as a closed area, so e.g. the two boxes may share
an edge and the containment check would still pass.

comment.shortText: Determines whether the box contains a given point.
comment.text:
Checks whether the point is inside the box's enclosed region.
The box is treated as a closed area,
so points on the boundary of the box will return true.

comment.shortText: Grows the box to include a given point.
comment.text:
Extends the box's bounding edges, if needed, to encapsulate the given point.
If the point is already inside the box, this function does nothing.
the box to potentially grow
the point that the box should grow to include

comment.shortText: Computes the smallest bounding box that contains all of the provided points.
comment.text:
If the provided array is empty, this method returns a box with `minX` and
`minY` set to `Infinity` and `maxX` and `maxY` set to `-Infinity`.
the points to contain

comment.shortText: Determines where the specified point lies in relation to the given box.
comment.text:
The returned value is a binary OR of the possible values
{@link OUT_MIN_X}, {@link OUT_MAX_X}, {@link OUT_MIN_Y}, and {@link OUT_MAX_Y}
indicating, for each side, whether the point lies beyond that edge. If the point
is inside the box, this function returns the value 0.

comment.shortText: Expands a box by a given amount in all directions.
comment.text:
Forms a new box with bounding edges `[(minX - amount) (minY - amount) (maxX + amount) (maxY + amount)]`.

The `amount` parameter is allowed to be negative, which effectively shrinks the box.
the box to grow
amount to expand from each edge. Is allowed to be negative.

comment.shortText: Determines whether two boxes overlap.
comment.text:
This function checks whether the two boxes intersect, as areas. Both boxes are treated as closed
regions, so e.g. this function will return true if the boxes share only a single edge.

The similar function {@link boxComputeIntersection} can compute the overlap region.
first box to check for overlap
second box to check for overlap

comment.shortText: Determines whether this box represents an empty area.
comment.text:
A box is considered empty if its `maxX` is less than or equal to its `minX` or
its `maxY` is less than or equal to its `minY`.

This function handles `Infinity`, `-Infinity`, and `NaN` values:
- Any box that contains a NaN edge is considered empty
- Edges with non-finite values are compared according to normal mathematical rules, so e.g. the
   [-∞, +∞]×[-∞, +∞] box is NOT empty, but the [+∞, -∞]×[-1, 1] box IS empty.

comment.shortText: Construct a new box given `minX`, `minY`, `maxX`, and `maxY` bounding values.

comment.text: min-X boundary of the box, which is typically the _left_ edge

min-Y boundary of the box, which could be the _top_ OR the _bottom_ edge of the box depending on how your
 rendering and coordinate systems are laid out.
max-X boundary of the box, which is typically the _right_ edge

min-Y boundary of the box, which could be the _top_ OR the _bottom_ edge of the box depending on how your
 rendering and coordinate systems are laid out.

comment.shortText: Scales a box by a fixed scalar in both directions.

comment.text: the box to scale
the value by which to multiply all of the box's components

comment.shortText: Compute the bounds of the image of this box after applying a 2D affine transformation.
comment.text:
This function calculates the minimum bounds that will contain the image after applying a transformation
to the given bounding box. Note that the actual geometric result of transforming a given
box may not be an axis-aligned box! For example, spinning the [-1, 1]×[-1, 1] box 45° clockwise yields a diamond
connecting the four points (√2, 0), (0, √2), (-√2, 0), (0, -√2). The bounding box of _that diamond_
is [-√2, √2]×[-√2, √2].
the box to transform
the affine transformation to apply to the box

comment.shortText: Translate a box by an offset in the x- and y- directions.

comment.text: the box to translate
the amount to translate in the x direction
the amount to translate in the y direction

comment.shortText: Creates a new Line object in memory, with all values initialized to `NaN`.
comment.text:
Data allocation functions like lineAlloc() are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can
severely hurt code readability and maintainability, so it's best to avoid
such optimization if you can.

comment.shortText: Copies the values from the given line into a new line.

comment.text: the source line from which values should be copied

comment.shortText: Determines if the point is on the line
comment.text:
This function tests whether the point lies along the line's geometry,
using allowed error _ε_ = 1e-8.
the line to inspect
the point to check whether it's on the line

comment.shortText:
Gets a point along the line, parameterized according to distance along its
direction vector.
comment.text:
Retrieves a point on the line's geometry according to moving distance _t_
along the direction vector from its initial point.

Synonymous to {@link rayGetPointAt}.
the line to inspect
distance along the line at which to compute point

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the two given lines, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the first and second line meet. If the lines are parallel and not overlapping,
this function returns no intersection. If the lines are completely overlapping,
this function returns the first line's initial point.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the first line's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the first line's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the second line's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the second line's parameterization
the first line to intersect
the second line to find intersection with

comment.shortText: Computes all locations at which a line crosses a given polyline.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the line's geometry
according to {@link ILine} parameterization. (See {@link lineGetPointAt}.)

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would hit the intersections if one were to start from -∞ and travel toward +∞ along the line's
direction vector.

Almost equivalent to {@link polylineIntersectLineIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the line's geometry.

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the given line and ray, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the line and ray meet. If the ray starts on one side of the line and points away from it,
or they are parallel, this function returns no intersection.
If the ray and line are the same (i.e. they are parallel and coincide with one another),
this function returns the line's initial point.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the line's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the line's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the ray's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the ray's parameterization

Almost equivalent to {@link rayIntersectLine}, except the returned intersection reverses its _t0_ and _t1_.
the line to intersect
the ray to find intersection with

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the given line and segment, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the line and line segment meet.
If the line "misses" the segment, this function returns no intersection.
If the line completely overlaps the segment, this function returns the line's initial point.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the line's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the line's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the segment's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the segment's parameterization

Almost equivalent to {@link segmentIntersectLine}, except the returned intersection reverses its _t0_ and _t1_.
the line to intersect
the segment to find intersection with

comment.shortText: Determines the closest the line comes to a given point
comment.text:
This measures the perpendicular distance of the point to the line's
direction vector. If the point lies on the line, this function returns 0.

To get the signed distance of the point to the line, which additionally
encodes which half-plane the point lies within, see
{@link lineNearestSignedDistanceToPoint}.
the line to inspect
the reference point to check for closest distance

comment.shortText: Determines the closest _signed_ distance the line comes to a given point
comment.text:
This measures the perpendicular distance of the point to the line's
direction vector. A _positive_ return value means that the point lies on the side of the line
rotated from its direction vector in the x+ to y+ direction ("left" or counter-clockwise in the
standard Cartesian coordinate system), while a _negative_ return value means it lies in the other half-plane
("right" or clockwise in the standard Cartesian coordinate system).

If the point lies on the line, this function returns 0.

To get the (unsigned) distance of the point to the line, see
{@link lineNearestSignedDistanceToPoint}.
the line to inspect
the reference point to check for closest distance

comment.shortText: Projects a point onto the given line, returning the distance _t_ along the line where it falls.
comment.text:
This function basically computes the dot product of the relative vector from the line's initial
point to the given point.

To find the closest point at which the line comes to the given point, which is the image
of the point projected onto the line, see {@link lineGetClosestPoint}.
line to inspect
point to project onto the line

comment.shortText: Construct a new line given an (x0, y0) initial point and (dirX, dirY) direction vector.
comment.text:
This function creates a new line from given values. The (dirX, dirY) values given should
describe a unit vector: no checks or operations are done internally to guarantee that is so.
x-coordinate of the line's initial point
y-coordinate of the line's initial point

x-coordinate of the line's direction vector, which should form a unit vector
 along with the provided `dirY`

y-coordinate of the line's direction vector, which should form a unit vector
 along with the provided `dirX`

comment.shortText: Construct a line that passes through two given points.
comment.text:
The constructed line will have its initial point set to the given `from` point,
and its direction initialized to pass through the `to` point (on the positive side
of the line, i.e. _t_ > 0). The direction vector will be properly normalized even if
the `from` and `to` points are not one unit apart.

If the two points are the same, the returned line will have the same initial point as
the `from` argument and a (NaN, NaN) direction vector.
the first point to pass through
the second point to pass through

comment.shortText: Transforms a line by an affine matrix.
comment.text:
This function computes the result of applying a transform to the line's geometry.
The resulting initial point will be the result of applying the given transform to the original
initial point, and its direction will be the result of applying any rotations or shears from
the matrix. The resulting direction vector will be correctly normalized when applicable.

Affine transformations and their specifics within Math2d are described in more detail
in the {@link vecTransformBy} docs.

Synonymous to {@link rayTransformBy}.
the line to transform
the affine transform to apply

comment.shortText: Computes on which side of the line a given point lies.
comment.text:
This method returns one of four possible values:

- `0`, if the point lies exactly along the line
- `1`, if the point lies in the halfplane defined by its direction vector sweeping in the x+ to y+ direction
  ("left" side, or counter-clockwise in the standard Cartesian coordinate system)
- `-1`, if the point lies in the halfplane defined by its direction vector sweeping in the x+ to y- direction
  ("right" side, or clockwise in the standard Cartesian coordinate system)
- `NaN`, if either of the point's coordinates or any of the line's components are NaN.

This measures the perpendicular distance of the point to the line's
direction vector. A _positive_ return value means that the point lies on the side of the line
rotated from its direction vector in the x+ to y+ direction ("left" or counter-clockwise in the
standard Cartesian coordinate system), while a _negative_ return value means it lies in the other half-plane
("right" or clockwise in the standard Cartesian coordinate system).

If the point lies on the line, this function returns 0.

To get the (unsigned) distance of the point to the line, see
{@link lineClosestDistanceToPoint}.
the line to inspect
the reference point to check for closest distance

comment.shortText: Creates a new mat2d object in memory, with all values initialized to `NaN`.
comment.text:
Data allocation functions like `mat2dAlloc()` are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can
severely hurt code readability and maintainability, so it's best to avoid
such optimization if you can.

comment.shortText: Copies the values from the given matrix into a new matrix.

comment.text: the matrix to copy

comment.shortText: Computes the determinant of the affine matrix
comment.text: The determinant in 2D space is given by `a * d - b * c`.
matrix to take determinant of

comment.shortText: Computes the affine transform corresponding to a given rotation, in radians
comment.text:
Calculates the matrix that would yield a rotation of `theta` radians around the origin.
The rotation is from the `x+` to `y+` direction, which is _counter-clockwise_ in the
standard Cartesian coordinate system or _clockwise_ in most standard graphics
coordinate systems, as in Canvas and the DOM.
angle in radians to create rotation for

comment.shortText: Computes the affine transform corresponding to a given (tx, ty) translation

comment.text: the x translation component
the y translation component

comment.shortText: Returns the identity affine matrix, `[1 0 0 1 0 0]`
Computes the inverse of the given 2d affine matrix

comment.text: the matrix to invert

comment.shortText: Returns whether the matrix is an orthogonal matrix.
comment.text:
An orthogonal matrix is defined as one whose rows and columns are orthogonal unit vectors.
(For a 2d affine matrix, this is constrained to its first 2x2 submatrix, i.e. excluding the translation.)

This is a useful property for a matrix because it means the transform preserves lengths and angles,
so in particular it preserves normals.
the matrix to check for orthogonality

comment.shortText: Returns whether the matrix corresponds to only a translation.
comment.text:
Affine translation matrices have the form

```
⎡1 0 tx⎤
⎣0 1 ty⎦
```
the matrix to inspect

comment.shortText: Computes the result of affine matrix multiplication _m1_ × _m2_.
comment.text:
The resulting matrix is equivalent to a transform that first applies _m2_ and then applies
_m1_; that is, `(m1×m2)v = m1(m2×v)`.

Affine matrix multiplication is defined by

```
⎡m1.a m1.c m1.e⎤ ⎡m2.a m2.c m2.e⎤   ⎡r.a r.c r.e⎤
⎢m1.b m1.d m1.f⎥ ⎢m2.b m2.d m2.f⎥ = ⎢r.b r.d r.f⎥
⎣   0    0    1⎦ ⎣   0    0    1⎦   ⎣  0   0   1⎦
```

where:
 - `r.a = m1.a * m2.a + m1.c * m2.b`
 - `r.b = m1.b * m2.a + m1.d * m2.b`
 - `r.c = m1.a * m2.c + m1.c * m2.d`
 - `r.d = m1.b * m2.c + m1.d * m2.d`
 - `r.e = m1.a * m2.e + m1.c * m2.f + m1.e`
 - `r.f = m1.b * m2.e + m1.c * m2.f + m1.f`
the first matrix to multiply
the second matrix to multiply

comment.shortText: Construct a new matrix given component values.
comment.text:
The resulting matrix will have the shape

```
⎡a c e⎤
⎣b d f⎦
```
col 1, row 1 component, usually called `m11` in a 4x4 graphics matrix
col 1, row 2 component, usually called `m12` in a 4x4 graphics matrix
col 2, row 1 component, usually called `m21` in a 4x4 graphics matrix
col 2, row 2 component, usually called `m22` in a 4x4 graphics matrix
col 3, row 1 component, usually called `tx` or `m41` in a 4x4 graphics matrix
col 3, row 2 component, usually called `ty` or `m42` in a 4x4 graphics matrix

comment.shortText: Applies a rotation in radians to the given matrix, returning the result.
comment.text:
This is equivalent to _left_-multiplying the matrix by a rotation transform; that is,
the result of this function is equivalent to a transform that first applies the matrix _mat_
and then rotates according to the angle _theta_.

The rotation is from the `x+` to `y+` direction, which is _counter-clockwise_ in the
standard Cartesian coordinate system or _clockwise_ in most standard graphics
coordinate systems, as in Canvas and the DOM.
the matrix to transform
rotation angle in radians to apply on top of the given matrix

comment.shortText: Applies a scaling transform on top of the given affine matrix, returning the result.
comment.text:
Multiplies all components of the matrix by a given scalar value.

This is equivalent to _left_-multiplying the matrix by a scaling transform; that is,
the result of this function is equivalent to a transform that first applies the matrix _mat_
and then scales in both the x- and y-directions according to _scale_.
the matrix to transform

comment.shortText: Applies a translation on top of the given matrix, returning the result.
comment.text:
This is equivalent to _left_-multiplying the matrix by a translation transform; that is,
the result of this function is equivalent to a transform that first applies the matrix _mat_
and then translates according to (+tx, +ty).
the matrix to transform
x-component of the translation to apply
y-component of the translation to apply

comment.text:
Data allocation functions like `polygonAlloc()` are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can
severely hurt code readability and maintainability, so it's best to avoid

comment.text: This function makes no attempt to identify trivial or "empty" sides.

comment.shortText: Computes the total perimeter length of this polygon.

comment.text: the polygon whose perimeter should be measured

comment.shortText:
Computes a point along the polygon's perimeter, parameterized according to linear interpolation between
adjacent vertices, cycling back to the start after its last vertex.
comment.text:
A polygon with _N_ sides is parameterized according to _t_, where integer values of _t0_ correspond to the polygon's
vertices in order, and smooth values of _t0_ therein interpolate linearly between adjacent vertices, with an
additional segment connecting the last vertex to the first.

the parameter variable at which a point should be calculated

comment.shortText: Returns the length of a polygon's side by index, starting at 0.
comment.text:
The given side index must be in the range [0, N) for a polygon with _N_ vertices:
this function does not accommodate "cycling" of polygon side indices.
the polygon whose side should be measured
the side index to measure, starting at 0

comment.shortText: Returns a polygon's side by given index as a segment, starting at 0.
comment.text:
The given side index must be in the range [0, N) for a polygon with _N_ vertices:
this function does not accommodate "cycling" of polygon side indices. If an out of range
index is given, this function returns a segment with all `NaN` values.
the polygon to inspect
which side to return, starting with 0

comment.shortText: Computes all locations at which a polygon crosses a given line.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the polygon's geometry
according to the {@link IPolygon} parameterization: integer values of _t0_ correspond to the polygon's
vertices in order, and smooth values of _t0_ therein interpolate linearly between adjacent vertices, with an
additional segment connecting the last vertex to the first.

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would visit those locations if one were to travel around the polygon's perimeter in the
order of its vertices.

Almost equivalent to {@link lineIntersectPolygonIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the polygon's geometry.
the polygon to intersect
the line to find intersections with

vertices in order, and smooth values of _t0_ therein interpolate linearly between adjacent vertices, with an
additional segment connecting the last vertex to the first.

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would visit those locations if one were to travel around the polygon's perimeter in the
order of its vertices.

Almost equivalent to {@link rayIntersectPolygonIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the polygon's geometry.

comment.shortText: Computes total length of polyline
Returns the number of individual line segments in this polyline
comment.text:
This function computes the number of line segments represented by this polyline,
which is always `Math.max(0, poly.length / 2 - 1)`. This function makes no effort to identify and filter
"trivial" or "empty" segments that may exist along its path.

comment.shortText: Returns the number of vertices in this polyline
comment.text:
Always equal to `poly.length / 2`. This function makes no attempt to remove repeated
or NaN vertices, for instance.

comment.shortText: Retrieves a vertex from this polyline's geometry, starting at index 0
Computes all locations at which a polyline crosses a given line.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the polyline's geometry
according to the {@link IPolyline} parameterization:
values of _t0_ are between 0 and the polyline's vertex count minus 1, and smooth values of _t0_ therein
signify linear interpolation between adjacent vertices along the polyline's geometry.

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would visit those locations if one were to travel from the polyline's start to its end
along its segments.

Almost equivalent to {@link lineIntersectPolylineIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the polyline's geometry.

comment.shortText: Computes all locations at which a polyline crosses a given ray.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the polyline's geometry
according to the {@link IPolyline} parameterization:
values of _t0_ are between 0 and the polyline's vertex count minus 1, and smooth values of _t0_ therein
signify linear interpolation between adjacent vertices along the polyline's geometry.

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would visit those locations if one were to travel from the polyline's start to its end
along its segments.

Almost equivalent to {@link rayIntersectPolylineIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the polyline's geometry.

comment.shortText: Computes all locations at which a polyline crosses a given line segment.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the polyline's geometry
according to the {@link IPolyline} parameterization:
values of _t0_ are between 0 and the polyline's vertex count minus 1, and smooth values of _t0_ therein
signify linear interpolation between adjacent vertices along the polyline's geometry.

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would visit those locations if one were to travel from the polyline's start to its end
along its segments.

Almost equivalent to {@link segmentIntersectPolylineIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the polyline's geometry.

comment.shortText: Returns whether the polyline's last vertex equals its first
comment.text:
Computes whether the polyline forms a closed shape, i.e. its last vertex
is the same as its first. As a special case, the empty polyline `[]` is
considered closed.

comment.shortText: Finds the closest the polyline comes to a given reference point.
comment.text:
The returned value _t_ is defined according to the {@link IPolyline} parameterization:
values of _t0_ are between 0 and the polyline's vertex count minus 1, and smooth values of T
signify linear interpolation between the two adjacent vertices along the polyline's geometry.

This function returns the squared euclidean distance in the `distanceValue` field of the result.
the polyline to inspect
the point to measure distance to

comment.shortText: Transforms a polyline by an affine matrix.
comment.text:
Simply transforms each of the polyline's vertices by the given matrix.
Affine transformations and their specifics within Math2d are described in more detail
in the {@link vecTransformBy} docs.
polyline to transform
affine transform to apply

comment.shortText: Trims a polyline to a range of its _t_ parameter.
comment.text:
This function trims geometry from either or both ends of the polyline, kind of like a "substring"
operation. Note that fractional values are allowed on the bounding _t_ parameters, which may slice off
only parts of segments to form new vertices.

A polyline's parameterization is defined according to _t_, where
values of _t_ are between 0 and the polyline's vertex count minus 1, and smooth values of _t_ therein
signify linear interpolation between adjacent vertices along the polyline's geometry.

Both the `tStart` and `tEnd` parameters will be clamped to their allowed domains [0, _N_-1] for a
polyline of _N_ vertices.
the polyline to trim

comment.shortText:
minimum _t_ value to include. The resulting polyline will have its last vertex at
 the point described by this value on the original polyline. Internally, this value will be clamped
 to the allowed domain `[0, poly.length/2 - 1]`.
Creates a new Ray object in memory, with all values initialized to `NaN`.
comment.text:
Data allocation functions like `rayAlloc()` are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can
severely hurt code readability and maintainability, so it's best to avoid
such optimization if you can.

comment.shortText: Copies the values from the given ray into a new ray.

comment.text: source ray from which values should be copied

comment.shortText: Determines if the point is on the ray
comment.text:
This function tests whether the point lies along the ray's geometry,
using allowed error _ε_ = 1e-8. The point must lie on the positive side
 of the ray (_t_ > 0).
the ray to inspect
point to check whether it's on the ray

comment.shortText:
Gets a point along the ray, parameterized according to distance along its
direction vector.
comment.text:
Retrieves a point on the ray's geometry according to moving distance _t_
along the direction vector from its initial point. This function does allow
negative values of _t_, returning points in the direction "behind" the ray.

Synonymous to {@link lineGetPointAt}.
the ray to inspect
distance along the ray at which to compute point

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the given ray and line, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the ray and line meet. If the ray starts on one side of the line and points away from it,
or they are parallel, this function returns no intersection.
If the ray and line are the same (i.e. they are parallel and coincide with one another),
this function returns the ray's initial point.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the ray's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the ray's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the line's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the line's parameterization

Almost equivalent to {@link lineIntersectRay}, except the returned intersection reverses its _t0_ and _t1_.
the ray to intersect
the line to intersect

comment.shortText: Computes all locations at which a ray crosses a given polyline.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the ray's geometry
according to {@link IRay} parameterization:
_t0_ ≥ 0, corresponds to travel of distance _t0_ along the ray's direction vector. (See {@link rayGetPointAt}.)

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would hit the intersections if one were to start from the ray's initial point and
shoot along its direction vector.

Almost equivalent to {@link polylineIntersectRayIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the ray's geometry.

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the two rays, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the two rays meet. If the rays point away or "miss" each other,
or they are parallel, this function returns no intersection.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the first ray's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the ray's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the second ray's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the ray's parameterization
the first ray to intersect
the second ray to intersect

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the ray and the segment, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the ray and segment meet. If the ray "misses" the segment,
this function returns no intersection. For edge cases where the ray completely overlaps the segment,
or starts within the segment, this function returns the _first_ point that the intersection occurs,
according to the ray's parameterization.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the ray's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the ray's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the segment's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the segment's parameterization

Almost equivalent to {@link segmentIntersectRay}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed.
the ray to intersect
the segment to intersect

comment.shortText: Constructs a ray from an initial point, pointing in the direction of a target point.
comment.text:
This function initializes a ray with a given `from` initial point, and with a direction vector
that goes through the target `to` point. The direction vector will be normalized even if `from`
and `to` are not one unit apart.

If `from` and `to` are the same point, the returned vector will still have the `from` initial
point but its direction vector will be (NaN, NaN).
initial point of the ray
point that the ray should go through

comment.shortText: Determines the closest the ray comes to a given reference point
comment.text:
If the point lies on the positive side of the ray (_t_ ≥ 0), this function
finds the projection of the point onto the ray's geometry.
If the point lies on the negative side of the ray (_t_ < 0),
this function returns the ray's initial point.

This function returns the squared distance in the result's `distanceValue`.
This is preferred over returning the (non-squared) distance because points
behind the ray need to measure distance to the ray's initial point, which would otherwise involve a square root.
If you know the point lies in front of the ray, and want to measure the distance while avoiding a square
root, prefer {@link lineNearestDistanceToPoint}. To determine which side of the ray a point lies on,
see {@link lineProjectPoint}.
the ray to inspect
the reference point to project onto the ray

comment.shortText: Construct a new ray given an (x0, y0) initial point and (dirX, dirY) direction vector.
comment.text:
This function creates a new ray from given values. The (dirX, dirY) values given should
describe a unit vector: no checks or operations are done internally to guarantee that is so.
x-coordinate of the ray's initial point
y-coordinate of the ray's initial point

x-coordinate of the ray's direction vector, which should form a unit vector
 along with the provided `dirY`

y-coordinate of the ray's direction vector, which should form a unit vector
 along with the provided `dirX`

comment.shortText: Transforms a ray by an affine matrix.
comment.text:
This function computes the result of applying a transform to the ray's geometry.
The resulting initial point will be the result of applying the given transform to the original
initial point, and its direction will be the result of applying any rotations or shears from
the matrix. The resulting direction vector will be correctly normalized when applicable.

Affine transformations and their specifics within Math2d are described in more detail
in the {@link vecTransformBy} docs.

Synonymous to {@link lineTransformBy}.
the ray to transform
the affine transform to apply

comment.shortText: Creates a new Segment object in memory, with all values initialized to `NaN`.
comment.text:
Data allocation functions like `segmentAlloc()` are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can
severely hurt code readability and maintainability, so it's best to avoid
such optimization if you can.

comment.shortText: Retrieves the starting endpoint (_t_ = 0) of the segment, as a vector.

comment.text: segment to inspect

comment.shortText: Retrives the ending endpoint (_t_ = 1) of the segment, as a vector.

comment.text: segment to inspect

comment.shortText: Computes the length of the line segment
comment.text: This is simply `√((x1 - x0)² + (y1 - y0)²)`.
segment to measure

comment.shortText: Computes the squared length of the line segment
comment.text: This is simply `(x1 - x0)² + (y1 - y0)²`.
segment to measure

comment.shortText:
Gets a point along the line segment, parameterized according to linear interpolation
between its endpoints.
comment.text:
A segment is parameterized according to linear interpolation between its endpoints,
where _t_ = 0 represents its starting vertex and _t_ = 1 its ending vertex.
Smooth values of _t_ within that range will move along the segment, so for example
_t_ = 0.5 is its midpoint.

This function does allow for _t_ values outside the range `[0, 1]`, which will return
points in the same direction as the segment but outside in either direction.
the segment to inspect
linear ratio along the segment to return

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the given segment and line, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the line segment and line meet.
If the line "misses" the segment, this function returns no intersection.
If the line completely overlaps the segment, this function returns the segment's starting vertex.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the segment's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the segment's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the line's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the line's parameterization

Almost equivalent to {@link lineIntersectSegment}, except the returned intersection reverses its _t0_ and _t1_.
the segment to intersect
the line to find intersection with

comment.shortText: Computes all locations at which a line segment meets a given polyline.
comment.text:
For each returned intersection, the intersection's _t0_ describes where the point fell on the segment's geometry
according to {@link ISegment} parameterization:
linear interpolation between its endpoints where _t0_ = 0 represents its starting vertex
and _t0_ = 1 its ending vertex.
Smooth values of _t_ within that range will move along the segment, so for example
_t0_ = 0.5 is its midpoint.

The returned points will be sorted by _t0_ increasing, i.e. they will be sorted according to the
order in which one would visit those locations if one were to travel from the line segment's starting
vertex to its ending vertex.

Almost equivalent to {@link polylineIntersectSegmentIterator}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed
and the returned intersections are sorted according to the segment's geometry.
the segment to intersect
the polyline to find intersections with

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the ray and the segment, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the ray and segment meet. If the ray "misses" the segment,
this function returns no intersection. For edge cases where the ray completely overlaps the segment,
or starts within the segment, this function returns the _first_ point that the intersection occurs,
according to the segment's parameterization.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the segment's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the segment's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the ray's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the ray's parameterization

Almost equivalent to {@link rayIntersectSegment}, except the _t0_ and _t1_ values are reversed.
the segment to intersect
the ray to find intersection with

comment.shortText: Computes the intersection point between the two line segments, if it exists.
comment.text:
Finds the location at which the two segments meet. If the two segments "miss" each other,
this function returns no intersection. If the two segments overlap along an entire interval
(i.e. they are parallel and lie partly on top of each other), this function returns the first
point they have in common, according to the first segment's parameterization.

The returned value is an {@link IPointIntersectionResult} object which will have have the
`exists` flag set to `true` iff an intersection was found. It additionally
has the following fields, if the intersection exists:

- `x` – the x-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `y` – the y-coordinate of the point of intersection
- `t0` – where along the first segment's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the first segment's parameterization
- `t1` – where along the second segment's geometry the intersection was found,
     according to the second segment's parameterization
the first segment to intersect
the second segment to find intersections with

comment.shortText: Finds the closest the segment comes to a given reference point.
comment.text: This function returns the squared euclidean distance in the `distanceValue` field of the result.
segment to inspect
point to measure squared distance to

comment.text:
Data allocation functions like `vecAlloc()` are useful to hold results of
Math2d function calls in inner loops of performance critical workflows.

As with any optimization, you don't need it until you've profiled your
application! Getting into temp variable management and shared state can

comment.shortText: Copies the values from the given vector into a new vector.

comment.text: the vector to copy

comment.shortText: Computes the two-dimensional cross product of the two vectors.
comment.text:
The two-dimensional cross product is defined to be the scalar value:

```
u × v = u.x * v.y - u.y * v.x
```

Note that the cross product is antisymmetric, i.e. `u × v = -v × u`.
the first vector
the vector to cross with the first

comment.shortText: Computes the straight-line (Euclidean) distance between the two points

comment.text: the first point
the second point, to which distance should be measured from the first

comment.shortText: Computes the squared straight-line (i.e. Euclidean) distance between the two points

comment.text: the first point
the second point to which squared distance should be measured

comment.shortText: Computes the dot product of the two vectors, i.e. `u.x * v.x + u.y * v.y`.

comment.text: the first vector
the vector to dot with the first

comment.shortText: Computes the straight-line length (i.e. Euclidean norm) of the given vector.
comment.text: Equivalent to `√(v.x² + v.y²)`.
the vector whose length should be measured

comment.shortText: Computes the squared straight-line length (i.e. square of the Euclidean norm) of the given vector.
comment.text: Equivalent to `v.x² + v.y²`.
the vector whose squared length should be measured

comment.shortText: Computes the Manhattan length of the given vector, i.e. `|v.x| + |v.y|`.

comment.text: the vector whose Manhattan length should be measured

comment.shortText: Performs a linear interpolation between the two vectors. The `r` parameter is allowed to be outside `[0, 1]`.

comment.text: the vector to start interpolation from
the vector to end interpolation with

the ratio to interpolate the two vectors, with _r_ = 0 returning the first vector `u` and _r_ = 1 returning
 the second vector `v`

comment.shortText: Computes the Manhattan distance between the two points.
comment.text: Equivalent to `|v.x - u.x| + |v.y - u.y|`.
the first point
the point to measure manhattan distance to from the first point

comment.shortText:
Normalizes the vector to be length 1. If the given vector is the zero-vector, this method
returns `(NaN, NaN)`.

comment.text: the vector to normalize

comment.shortText: Returns the 2d origin vector, `(0, 0)`.

Computes the perp of the given vector, as defined by `vecPerp(a, b) = (-b, a)`.
This is equivalent to a counter-clockwise rotation in the standard plane.

comment.text: the vector whose perp should be calculated

comment.shortText: Construct a new vector given an `x` and `y` value.

comment.text: x-coordinate of the vector
y-coordinate of the vector

comment.shortText: Scales both coordinates of this vector by a given scalar.

comment.text: the vector to scale
the value by which the vector's components should be scaled

comment.shortText: Computes `u - v`, i.e. subtracting the second vector from the first.

comment.text: the first vector
the second vector

comment.shortText: Multiplies the vector by an affine matrix.
comment.text:
This computes a left multiplication of the vector by a matrix, i.e. _M_ × _v_.

Per usual linear algebra rules, multiplying the vector `(x, y)` according to an affine matrix
`[a b c d e f]` is defined by:

```
⎡a c e⎤ ⎛x⎞   ⎛ax + cy + e⎞
⎢b d f⎥ ⎜y⎟ = ⎜bx + dy + f⎟
⎣0 0 1⎦ ⎝1⎠   ⎝     1     ⎠
```
the vector to transform
the matrix to multiply this vector by
